revision.comment: default color for consistency with other satellites
revision.text:
{{Infobox planet |name = Carme |image = Carmé.jpg |discoverer = [[Seth Barnes Nicholson|S. B. Nicholson]] |discovered = July 30, 1938{{cite journal |last=Nicholson |first=S. B. |title=Two New Satellites of Jupiter |journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific |year=1938 |volume=50 | pages=292–293 |url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu//full/seri/PASP./0050//0000292.000.html |doi=10.1086/124963 |bibcode=1938PASP...50..292N}} |mean_orbit_radius = 23,400,000 km{{cite journal |last=Jacobson |first=R. A. |title=The Orbits of Outer Jovian Satellites |journal=Astronomical Journal |year=2000 |volume=120 |issue=5 |pages=2679–2686 |doi=10.1086/316817 |bibcode=2000AJ....120.2679J|url=https://trs.jpl.nasa.gov/bitstream/2014/15175/1/00-1187.pdf }} |eccentricity = 0.25 |period = 702.28 d (1.9228 [[Year|a]]) |avg_speed = 2.253 km/s |inclination = {{nowrap|164.91° (to the [[ecliptic]])}}
167.53° (to Jupiter's equator) |satellite_of = [[Jupiter]] |mean_radius = ~23 km{{cite web |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/?sat_phys_par |publisher=[[JPL]] (Solar System Dynamics) |title=Planetary Satellite Physical Parameters |date=2008-10-24 |accessdate=2008-12-12}} |surface_area = ~6600 km² |volume = ~51,000 km³ |mass = 1.3{{e|17}} kg |density = 2.6 g/cm³ (assumed) |surface_grav = ~0.017 [[Acceleration|m/s2]] (0.0017 ''g'') |escape_velocity = ~0.028 km/s |albedo = 0.04 (assumed) |single_temperature = ~124 K }} '''Carme''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɑr|m|iː}} {{respell|KAR|mee}}; {{lang-grc-gre|Κάρμη}}) is a [[retrograde motion|retrograde]] [[irregular satellite]] of [[Jupiter]]. It was discovered by [[Seth Barnes Nicholson]] at [[Mount Wilson Observatory]] in [[California]] in July 1938. It is named after the mythological [[Carme (mythology)|Carme]], mother by [[Zeus]] of [[Britomartis]], a [[Crete|Cretan]] goddess. ==History== Carme did not receive its present name until 1975;[http://www.cbat.eps.harvard.edu/iauc/02800/02846.html IAUC 2846: ''Satellites of Jupiter''] 1974 October 7 (naming the moon) before then, it was simply known as '''{{nowrap|Jupiter XI}}'''. It was sometimes called "[[Pan (mythology)|Pan]]"{{cite book| last=Payne-Gaposchkin|first=Cecilia|author2=Katherine Haramundanis|title=Introduction to Astronomy|year=1970|publisher=[[Prentice-Hall]]|location=Englewood Cliffs, N.J.|isbn=0-13-478107-4}} between 1955 and 1975 ([[Pan (moon)|Pan]] is now the name of a satellite of [[Saturn]]). It gives its name to the [[Carme group]], made up of irregular retrograde moons orbiting Jupiter at a distance ranging between 23 and 24 Gm and at an inclination of about 165°. Its orbital elements are as of January 2000. They are continuously changing due to [[Sun|solar]] and planetary perturbations. ==See also== *[[Irregular satellite]]s *[[Jupiter's moons in fiction]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070608214836/http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Jup_Carme Carme Profile] by [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov NASA's Solar System Exploration] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060901072706/http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/~jewitt/irregulars.html David Jewitt pages] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081206061458/http://www.dtm.ciw.edu/sheppard/satellites/jupsatdata.html Jupiter's Known Satellites] (by [[Scott S. Sheppard]]) {{Moons of Jupiter}} [[Category:Carme group]] [[Category:Moons of Jupiter]] [[Category:Irregular satellites]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 1938|19380730]]
